#Text=Disposal of fracking wastewater poses potential environmental problems
#Text=Wednesday , April 25 , 2012
#Text=A recent study by the United States Geological Survey ( USGS ) shows that the oil and gas industry are creating earthquakes .
#Text=New information from the Midwest region of the United States points out that these man-made earthquakes are happening more frequently than expected .

#Text=While more frequent earthquakes are less of a problem for regions like the Midwest , a geology professor from the University of Southern Indiana , Dr. Paul K. Doss , believes the disposal of wastewater from the hydraulic fracturing ( or " fracking " ) process used in extracting oil and gas has the possibility to pose potential problems for groundwater .

column1: #Text=Map showing significant earthquakes in the Midwest region of the United States .
#Text=It was analyzed to show links between felt earthquakes and energy development .
#Text=Image : United States Geological Survey .
#Text=" We are taking this fluid that has a whole host of chemicals in it that are useful for fracking and putting it back into the Earth , " Doss said .

#Text=" From a purely seismic perspective these are not big earthquakes that are going to cause damage or initiate , as far as we know , any larger kinds of earthquakes activity for Midwest . [ The issue ] is a water quality issue in terms of the ground water resources that we use .

#Text= If groundwater becomes contamin­ated , it takes years to decades to try to clean up an aquifer system , " University of New Brunswick professor Tom Al said .

column1: #Text=While the USGS group which conducted the study says it is unclear how the earthquake rates may be related to oil and gas production , they 've made the correlation between the disposal of wastewater used in fracking and the recent upsurge in earthquakes .

#Text=Because of the recent information surfacing that shows this connection between the disposal process and earthquakes , individual states in the United States are now passing laws regarding disposal wells .
#Text=The problem is that we have never , as a human society , engineered a hole to go four miles down in the Earth ’s crust that we have complete confidence that it wo n’t leak . — Dr. Paul K. Doss
#Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=The problem is that we have never , as a human society , engineered a hole to go four miles down in the Earth ’s crust that we have complete confidence that it wo n’t leak ,  Doss said .

#Text= A perfect case-in-point is the Gulf of Mexico oil spill in 2010 , that oil was being drilled at 18,000 feet but leaked at the surface .

#Text= You eliminate all the water-related issues that we ’re raising , and that peo­ple have raised in general across North America , " Al said .

column1: #Text=In New Brunswick liquefied propane gas has been used successfully in fracking some wells , but according to water specialist with the province ’s Natural Resources De­partment Annie Daigle , it may not be the go-to solution for New Brunswick due its geological makeup .
#Text="
